column4: Once you have copied the files run `sudo modprobe bcm43xx` and you should be able to connect.
How are you trying to connect?
Have you entered in the SSID? ( network name )?
I don't know much what to do beyond that, sorry. But just to be sure, what is the output of `sudo modprobe bcm43xx`?
That means at least that worked...
It depends on what your wireless interface is called...
then `sudo ifup eth1` and past the output
I really don't know very much, mabie somebody more knowlageable can help you out more.
All I can suggest is that you install network-manager-gnome as it automatically detects networks and other nice things like that.
